description: Rada Miskovic debates whether to publish evidence of past abuses or to promote the call for open, score-blind elections. She decides to focus her reporting on building a new future, believing hope will unite more people than outrage.
Rada meets with district council organizers and community leaders at Bar 101, gathering firsthand perspectives to frame the open elections as both a risk and opportunity for all residents.
Rada publishes a widely shared article highlighting the election movement as Stenograd’s first real chance at collective, score-blind governance. Her coverage sparks conversations citywide.

District councils formally announce Stenograd’s first open elections, with candidates of all backgrounds—including previously flagged and erased residents—stepping forward. Formal campaigns and debates begin, exposing old rivalries but also new alliances.

Transparent, analog voting overseen by Oksana Lintz and Lenart Kova proceeds smoothly despite attempts by Directorate loyalists to disrupt the process. Preliminary results show a decisive victory for grassroots and ghost candidates, paving the way for a new citywide civic assembly.
